Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Developing a Structured Student-guided Personalized Learning System for Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project develops novel adaptive techniques for web-based learning materials, and creates Algebra and Statistics content using those techniques. College textbooks and homework are being replaced with web-based learning materials that are highly-interactive, involving animations, learning questions, and auto-generated auto-graded homework/quiz exercises. The project develops those exercises to adjust (adapt) to the learner's performance as well as to the learner's preferences, providing a novel structured form of adaptivity that maximizes learning efficiency while reducing student anxiety, in contrast to many other proposed adaptive techniques. The project creates new content for the topics of Algebra and for Statistics, two critical subjects with which many college students struggle. The result will be greater success (and less failure) in Algebra and Statistics courses by young college students, leading to more graduates in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) fields, which contribute greatly to the nation's productivity and competitiveness. The techniques can be applied to many other STEM and non-STEM subjects, and for learning beyond college courses too.

This SBIR Phase II project develops novel adaptive techniques for web-based learning materials, called structured student-guided adaptive (SSGA) techniques. In contrast to some recent adaptive commercial products, SSGA preserves the ability of an instructor to maintain a structured path through the material, which is critical for keeping students in synch with lecture/discussion sessions, for enabling students to study with classmates, and more. Adaptivity comes in several forms, including auto-generating successively-harder problems based on correct completion of earlier problems, with explanations and source material carefully integrated to ensure students learn underlying concepts. Also, the adaptivity is in part guided by the student, who can choose to start with simpler or harder problems, or can auto-generate self-quizzes based on performance, selected material, and more. In contrast with other products, student-guided adaptivity gives students appropriate control over their learning, yielding a sense of empowerment and reducing anxiety that can inhibit learning. The project builds the authoring platform necessary to support SSGA material creation, building upon a previously-developed authoring framework for interactive web material. The project also creates new material for college algebra and statistics courses, whose high attrition rates can be reduced by replacing traditional textbooks/homework with SSGA material.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Freshman-level required courses in topics like math and statistics can greatly impact whether college students progress further in their studies. A high correlation exists between success in algebra and future academic/professional success. Math in general also plays an important prerequisite for all STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) disciplines, and having a trained workforce in such STEM disciplines is critical for the U.S.'s ongoing economic success. Many students entering college are not prepared for entry-level college courses.

The Phase I project focused on re-designing early math material by investigating if adapting the material to the individual learner's learning style would improve performance. For example, learning material can be written in many different configurations: mostly text, mostly videos, mostly learning questions, mostly exercises, or various hybrids. The project's experiments involving hundreds of students in college algebra showed that a carefully designed hybrid was most effective across all learner types. Our conclusion matches what the education community has come to know regarding adapting to learning style. Namely, the best approach is to provide all students with blended/hybrid material, rather than catering to their supposed learning style.

The Phase II project integrates student-guided adaptivity features as part of a series of highly-adaptive Math and Statistics zyBooks. We honed in on an integrated web-flow format wherein the zyBook has all learning and homework in a single flow; the user simply proceeds from top to bottom as they learn. Within each section, we created the best material possible by integrating both kinesthetic and auditory/visual elements into a blended lesson.  Students rarely read long passages of text or follow lengthy examples, thus we have moved to a "less-text, more action" approach. The zyBook uses just enough text to explain a basic concept or theory, followed immediately by activities that further explain, such as animations, learning questions, tools, and challenge exercises, all of which are "active" elements where the reader is actively doing something other than just reading. To enable the development of our proposed innovative adaptive learning approach, we also sought to expand and improve existing author tools to enable development by more authors. Our in-house animation tool for example was expanded to support images, equations, variable speed, and pausing. The development of the in-house progression builder challenge activity tool, provided authors with a template-based mechanism for creating new progressive challenge activities. Addition of this tool enables creation of more such activities by more authors and catalyze development of powerful math activities that addresses students desire for more practice, and that adapts by creating increasingly harder problems as the student masters simpler ones.

The introductory college level Algebra zyBook was completed in Phase II, which includes interactive and adaptive elements. Additional Math and Statistics materials were also developed as part of the Phase II to illustrate that the techniques proposed in this project apply beyond just Algebra and that other analytical subjects can reap similar improvements in student learning, motivation, and mastery of fundamental concepts. The titles developed as part of this project have served to strengthen the introductory math sequence within our catalog, enabled new opportunities for additional analytic courses within and beyond math, strengthened partnerships with traditional and non-traditional institutions, and hopefully helped a large number of students and instructors.

Furthermore, the Phase IIB project focused on extending the capabilities of our progression challenge activities involving programs. These activities are often used as “homework” and play a large role in an instructor’s decision to adopt zyBooks. From a student perspective, we have found that progression challenge activities also address students' desired for additional practice and review, serving as a form of self-quizzing. The proposed progression activities span across multiple analytic topics such as math and programming. We have introduced two new types of progression challenge activities, code output progression and programming progression. Code output progression challenge activities ask students to evaluate a small piece of code and determine the code's output. Programming progression challenge activities are complementary to code output progressions and ask students to write a small piece of code to achieve some desired output (or functionality). These activities are currently developed in XML and have a well-defined format so authors are able to create such activities starting from a simple template. To test for correctness, the code is sent to a remote server running on AWS that compiles and executes the code. The output produced by the code is then compared to the student's answer to ensure correctness.
